original_text: The immersed boundary method (IBM), proposed by Peskin for studying flow patterns around heart valves  [3], has been applied to a wide range of problems including arterial blood flow  [4], modelling of the cochlea  [5], modelling of red blood cells in Poiseuille flow  [6] and flows involving suspended particles  [7]. A comprehensive list of applications can be found in  [8]. The IBM is both a mathematical formulation and a numerical scheme for fluid–structure interaction problems. As mentioned above, in a classical fluid–structure interaction problem, the fluid and the structure are considered separately and then coupled together via some suitable jump conditions. In the IBM however, the structure–which is usually immersed in a Newtonian fluid–is viewed as being part of the surrounding fluid. This means that only a single equation of motion needs to be solved (i.e. a one-phase formulation). Additionally, the IBM allows the immersed structure to move freely over the underlying fluid mesh, alleviating the need for the remeshing required in a classical formulation.
original_translation: El método de frontera inmersa (IBM), propuesto por Peskin para estudiar patrones de flujo alrededor de válvulas cardíacas [3], se ha aplicado a una amplia gama de problemas que incluyen el flujo sanguíneo arterial [4], modelado de la cóclea [5], modelado de glóbulos rojos en flujo de Poiseuille [6] y flujos que involucran partículas suspendidas [7]. Una lista completa de aplicaciones se puede encontrar en [8]. El IBM es tanto una formulación matemática como un esquema numérico para problemas de interacción fluido-estructura. Como se mencionó anteriormente, en un problema clásico de interacción fluido-estructura, el fluido y la estructura se consideran por separado y luego se acoplan a través de algunas condiciones de salto adecuadas. Sin embargo, en el IBM, la estructura, que generalmente está inmersa en un fluido newtoniano, se ve como parte del fluido circundante. Esto significa que solo se necesita resolver una ecuación de movimiento (es decir, una formulación de una fase). Además, el IBM permite que la estructura inmersa se mueva libremente sobre la malla de fluido subyacente, aliviando la necesidad de remallado requerida en una formulación clásica.

A comprehensive list of applications can be found in  [8].
The IBM is both a mathematical formulation and a numerical scheme for fluid–structure interaction problems.
As mentioned above, in a classical fluid–structure interaction problem, the fluid and the structure are considered separately and then coupled together via some suitable jump conditions.
In the IBM however, the structure–which is usually immersed in a Newtonian fluid–is viewed as being part of the surrounding fluid.
This means that only a single equation of motion needs to be solved (i.e. a one-phase formulation).
Additionally, the IBM allows the immersed structure to move freely over the underlying fluid mesh, alleviating the need for the remeshing required in a classical formulation.

original_annotated_sentences:
The immersed boundary method (IBM), proposed by Peskin for studying flow patterns around heart valves [3], has been applied to a wide range of problems including arterial blood flow [4], modelling of the cochlea [5],
modelling of red blood cells in Poiseuille flow
[6] and flows involving suspended particles [7].
A comprehensive list of applications can be found in  [8].
The IBM is both a mathematical formulation and a numerical scheme for fluid–structure interaction problems.
As mentioned above, in a classical fluid–structure interaction problem, the fluid and the structure are considered separately and then coupled together via some suitable jump conditions.
In the IBM however, the structure–which is usually immersed in a Newtonian fluid–is viewed as being part of the surrounding fluid.
This means that only a single equation of motion needs to be solved (i.e. a one-phase formulation).
Additionally, the IBM allows the immersed structure to move freely over the underlying fluid mesh, alleviating the need for the remeshing required in a classical formulation.
original_annotated_samples:
The immersed boundary method (IBM), proposed by Peskin for studying flow patterns around heart valves [3], has been applied to a wide range of problems including arterial blood flow [4], modelling of the cochlea [5],
modelling of red blood cells in Poiseuille flow
[6] and flows involving suspended particles [7].
translated_annotated_samples:
El método de frontera inmersa (IBM), propuesto por Peskin para estudiar patrones de flujo alrededor de válvulas cardíacas [3], se ha aplicado a una amplia gama de problemas que incluyen el flujo sanguíneo arterial [4], modelado de la cóclea [5],
modelado de glóbulos rojos en flujo de Poiseuille
[6] y flujos que involucran partículas suspendidas [7].
modelling of red blood cells in Poiseuil.translated_text:
El método de frontera inmersa (IBM), propuesto por Peskin para estudiar patrones de flujo alrededor de válvulas cardíacas [3], se ha aplicado a una amplia gama de problemas que incluyen el flujo sanguíneo arterial [4], modelado de la cóclea [5],
modelado de glóbulos rojos en flujo de Poiseuille
[6] y flujos que involucran partículas suspendidas [7]. Una lista completa de aplicaciones se puede encontrar en [8]. El IBM es tanto una formulación matemática como un esquema numérico para problemas de interacción fluido-estructura. Como se mencionó anteriormente, en un problema clásico de interacción fluido-estructura, el fluido y la estructura se consideran por separado y luego se acoplan a través de algunas condiciones de salto adecuadas. Sin embargo, en el IBM, la estructura, que generalmente está inmersa en un fluido newtoniano, se ve como parte del fluido circundante. Esto significa que solo se necesita resolver una ecuación de movimiento (es decir, una formulación de una fase). Además, el IBM permite que la estructura inmersa se mueva libremente sobre la malla de fluido subyacente, aliviando la necesidad de remallado requerida en una formulación clásica.

studying flow patterns around heart valv.translated_key: patrones de flujo alrededor de válvulas cardíacas
original_annotated_sentences:
The immersed boundary method (IBM), proposed by Peskin for
studying flow patterns around heart valves
[3], has been applied to a wide range of problems including arterial blood flow [4], modelling of the cochlea [5], modelling of red blood cells in Poiseuille flow [6] and flows involving suspended particles [7].
A comprehensive list of applications can be found in  [8].
The IBM is both a mathematical formulation and a numerical scheme for fluid–structure interaction problems.
As mentioned above, in a classical fluid–structure interaction problem, the fluid and the structure are considered separately and then coupled together via some suitable jump conditions.
In the IBM however, the structure–which is usually immersed in a Newtonian fluid–is viewed as being part of the surrounding fluid.
This means that only a single equation of motion needs to be solved (i.e. a one-phase formulation).
Additionally, the IBM allows the immersed structure to move freely over the underlying fluid mesh, alleviating the need for the remeshing required in a classical formulation.
